Award.AwardTitle: Science and Social Justice Think Tank

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Kalamazoo College has received an award through the Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: Education and Human Resources program to hold a conference entitled, "Science and Social Justice Think Tank." The purpose of this working conference is to bring together (1) postsecondary STEM educators, (2) scholars, scientists, and public health professionals, and (3) higher education STEM thought leaders to consider, discuss, and plan for the inclusion of social justice issues in science. The conference includes several keynote addresses by leaders from various sectors who have expertise in science and social justice issues. These presentations are followed by small discussion groups composed of participants who have been working at the intersection of science and social justice. The participants will be tasked with articulating what science and social justice means, thinking about ways to extend and broaden the conversation, and developing a detailed plan for disseminating the products of the conference.

There has been significant attention to ethics in the natural sciences and considerable attention to the introduction of social justice topics in the undergraduate curricula in disciplines such as economics. However, there has been little consideration of issues of social justice, such as distribution of wealth, opportunities, and privileges within society, in the practice of the natural sciences. By tackling such considerations and how they can be integrated into undergraduate STEM education, the conference will contribute to the preparation of future scientists, as well as the education of a STEM-literate citizenry, providing them with the ability to evaluate STEM research in the context of its impact on society. Results of the conference will be shared through the Science and Social Justice Praxis website hosted at Kalamazoo College.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From April 21-24 2016, fifty social justice thinkers (teachers, professors, scholars, scientists, and health professionals) from around the country gathered together at the Kalamazoo College Arcus Center for Social Justice Leadership to deliberate on the emerging field of Science and Social Justice. This grant allowed for STEM practitioners in the fields of biology, physics, ecology, chemistry, agricultural science, medicine, mathematics, and environmental science to come together and think about how infusing topics and information of interest at the grassroots level could make STEM education accessible to many; in a phrase, Social Justice in STEM education.  In addition to folks who identified as STEM educators, this Think Tank included academic administrators, a science journalist, a photographic artist, and a creative non-fiction writer, making it a multifaceted event. The format was a series of oral presentations by experts in particular disciplines of STEM and non-STEM areas.  The presentations were then followed by small break out discussions that were centered on a specific question posed during the presentation, for which careful notes were taken.  The outcomes of the presentations and small group discussions can be summarized by the following four general themes that emerged: Who Gets to do Science and Why: keynote speakers Drs. Saundra McGuire and David Asai challenged us to think creatively of ways that we could increase the number of students from underrepresented groups (URGs) in STEM. Teaching the History of Science in Classrooms: keynote speakers Harriet Washington (journalist) and Dr. Jon Beckwith discussed how teaching the dark history of science and medicine can impact how the next generation of scientists think about and practice their trade. Teaching to Promote Science and Social Justice Research: keynote speakers Drs. John Vandemeer and Charles Ide introduced topics relating to environmental issues, and invited us to imagine the students who might engage in STEM with the earth as their platform. Students are more likely, they told us, to persist in STEM if they perceive that their efforts are being made for a greater cause.  And lastly, Considering Interdisciplinary Approaches to Science Teaching: keynote speakers Dr. Mary Beth Heffernan and Poet Debra Marquart demonstrated that interdisciplinary thinking can infuse social justice into science in ways that classical science thinking cannot. Dr. Mary Beth Heffernan showed the audience how her photographic lens was used to aid victims during the Ebola crisis in West Africa, while Poet Marquart used her poetic writings to shine a light on the issues of fracking in North Dakota. 

This Think Tank was a rich and diverse microcosm of our communities, wherein we envisioned how interdisciplinary thinking might impact students’ interest, persistence, and inclusion in STEM.
